abbr.description: Default styling for <abbr> tags, which should be used on the first mention of an abbreviation. It is often accompanied by a <dfn> tag in the same paragraph.

bulleted.description: In DLx projects, lists are often used semantically rather than stylistically, e.g. a phrase includes a list of words. As such, lists have no styling by default, and list styling needs to be explicitly set with the .bulleted or .numbered styles.

button.description: A basic button. This is applied automatically to buttons, but may also be applied using the .button class to any element.

cite.description: The <cite> element is used for titles of publications, etc.

code.description: The <code> element is used for both inline and standalone code blocks.

dfn.description: A <dfn> tag is used the first time an element is defined. The definition of the term should be given in the surrounding text.

em.description: Used for standard emphasis within text.

field.description: Styles an element as a form field. This style is automatically applied to various form elements, such as the <input type=text> element.

fieldset.description: Used for grouping inputs together under a heading (<legend>). Remember that flexbox does not work well with <fieldset>, so you may need to wrap the items inside <fieldset> in a <div>.

hanging.description: For blocks of text with a hanging indent.

input.description: Adding the .input class to any <input> element will style that element according to its type.

italic.description: Used for general italic styling. Other more semantic classes should be preferred over this one when possible.

label.description: Label elements. If the text inside the element is wrapped in a <span> element, that text will be styled as well.

link.description: The .link class is not automatically applied to anchor elements (<a>). It is, however, automatically applied to any anchor element that sits inside another inline element, such as <abbr> or <strong>, and to any element that sits inside an element whose content is usually inline, such as <p> or <h1>.

link-white.description: A white link rather than the standard blue. Used for dark backgrounds.

nav.description: The main navigation bar at the top of the page. Hover effects are not added.

numbered.description: For numbered lists. Because DLx often uses ordered lists where list styling is not wanted, the .numbered class is not automatically applied to <ol> elements, and must be applied manually.

orthographic.description: This class should be used when citing an orthographic representation of some data, e.g., when writing about writing systems.

phonemic.description: Used for phonemic representations of data.

phonetic.description: Used for phonetic representations of data.

reference-list.description: Styling for a bibliographic reference list. Note that each reference should be wrapped in a <p> tag inside of a <li> tag.

strong.description: Used to draw the reader's attention to a term or concept.

tooltip.description: Adding the .tooltip class to any element will make a tooltip display on hover or when the element is focused. The content of the tooltip is contained in the title attribute for that element. Note that tooltips do not work on <input> elements - place the .tooltip class on the <label> instead.

unicode.description: Used when a Unicode font is needed. More semantic styles such as .phonetic or .phonemic should be preferred over this one when possible.
